I'm Allison Beard. A few years ago, I noticed a weird thing. Crocs, those rubbery boat shoes that you used to see mostly on little kids, were suddenly extremely popular with teenagers. My kids' middle and high school friends were all wearing them everywhere, in lots of styles and colors, with socks and without. Then, earlier this year, the same thing happened with a different product, Stan Lee Insulated Mugs. This was a brand I knew from growing up. They made bottles that you usually brought outdoors. But now my 13-year-old daughter's entire city and suburban crew was buying the Quencher, a 30-ounce mug with a big handle and straw in different pastel shades and carrying them around, almost like trophies. I began to wonder, how do consumer goods like these suddenly move from under the radar or even uncool to totally trendy? Well, there's no better person to ask than our guest today. Terrence Riley was the chief marketing officer of Crocs during its resurgence, and he's now the president of Stanley. When I found out that he was there to shape the strategies that led to such success for both companies, I wanted to talk to him about how he did it. Terrence, welcome. Thank you very much. First let's talk about Crocs. How did you get teenagers so interested in wearing them? Well, I didn't do anything. We had an amazing team at Crocs, similar to Stanley. One day, Toria Roth, who was just fresh off of her internship at Crocs, she walked into my office, the CMO's office, and she said, Terrence, do you have a minute? She showed me a photo of Post Malone wearing Crocs. Post Malone is a very popular musician. Absolutely. He wasn't wearing them with any sort of irony. He just was wearing them. She said, this could be something for Crocs. I reached out to the folks that manage Post Malone, and I said, hey, would you be interested in a partnership or collaboration where Post could create his own Crocs? A few months later, the first celebrity collaboration with Crocs was born. I think it broke the Crocs website when they went live. We had more people waiting than we could handle. Obviously, that set the stage for multiple artists and brands over the following years to collaborate with Crocs. It was actually just a celebrity who liked the product initially. Is that how consumer brands should go about finding endorsers or influencers to be brand ambassadors? Well, sure. At the time, Crocs was a meme. The meme was, those holes are where your dignity leaks out. We knew, and certainly I knew, that we had a classic. We just needed to create more relevance for the brand. We didn't have an awareness problem at Crocs. We had a relevance opportunity. Post Malone was that real quick injection of relevance. Once he was on board, it allowed me to call almost any artist or any brand to collaborate. As an example, I was in Asia and I saw the popularity of Kentucky Fried Chicken in Asia. I reached out to the CMO of Kentucky Fried Chicken via LinkedIn while in Asia, asked him if he'd be interested in a Crocs KFC collaboration. Sure enough, you can go online today. We'll see those for $300, $400 in the secondary market today. That kind of hype became something that had its own inertia. It sounds like you have to have an awareness of the people and other brands that your ideal consumers care about. Then you establish and make those relationships happen, and that can work for any consumer brand? I'd like to think so. It might not be that easy. It starts with a risk. We took a risk. Crocs had been, I would say, fledgling for quite some time. Still, it was a very young brand, but it had its moment back in the early 2000s and really was just, I would say, just floating along. We took a risk. Post Malone was a risk, especially at the time. He hadn't quite reached the level of popularity that he enjoys today and he's earned today. A brand took a risk on that kind of artist and it sure paid off. Yeah. For those who don't know Post Malone, he has tattoos all over his face. It's definitely not someone I would intuitively associate with a brand like Crocs. Correct, but it was real. His fandom for Crocs was authentic and his fans knew that. That's also what's happened at Stanley. When you have that authenticity, you have gold that you can't really manufacture as hard as you try. We had something that was risky at the time, walking into senior leadership at Crocs to tell them we should be betting on Post Malone was a bit of a career risk for me, I'm sure. Taking that risk and listening was the key. Listening to that young associate who had her finger on the pulse of culture, listening to Post Malone's fans, and then on and on it went. Back at Crocs and then now at Stanley, when you're thinking of listening to consumers, how do you do it? Is it through social media? Is it through surveys, focus groups? The easiest thing in 2023 or 2020 when I joined Stanley as president is social media, but also listening to your team. It's probably rare that the CMO listens to an intern from a month ago, but that's what happened. Thank goodness that Toria had the courage to knock on the CMO's door. The first week when I joined Stanley, I interviewed my colleagues to say, hey, what's going well? What isn't? What's start and continue? Lauren Solomon, one of our brilliant sales associates at Stanley told me that there was a group in Utah that had a genuine love for this little product called the Quencher. When Lauren told me about the Buy Guide and their love for the Quencher, I knew that was a place to start going from what had been a traditional male green brand that your grandmother brought to work as a teacher or your grandfather brought to the construction site. I knew if those three women in Utah, the Buy Guide, loved us like I thought they loved us, we had something. The Buy Guide is, let's call them influencers, but they have an amazing audience largely based in Utah at the time when we started this. Sure enough, we created a partnership with the Buy Guide that started with 500 units which had become 5,000 units and then 5 million units of the Quencher. We've turned the Stanley brand into a proprietary eponym, which is something I've learned a couple of months ago of Band-Aid, Kleenex, Q-Tip, Xerox, Stanley. Is that opportunity for growth into different customer segments why you were interested in joining this very traditional, very staid company? Exactly. It was a different challenge where Crocs did not need awareness help, they needed relevance help. I knew that Stanley needed awareness help. People knew it. Like I said, they, ah, my dad had one in the garage, but you don't make anything for me is what I was told. Even my daughters, when I joined Crocs, my daughters were like, dad, Crocs is not cool. Why would you work for Crocs? When I let my daughters know I was leaving for Stanley, they were like, why would you leave Crocs? Are you kidding me? They were like, Crocs is the coolest thing ever. And it's a remarkable thing in my personal life that has happened through the lens of my two daughters to know that their old man is kind of doing the right thing. And that's what I knew we would have at Stanley. You get this rare chance to take a 107-year-old heritage brand from this green bottle who people knew about, but you don't make one for me. I knew that if we could make one for them, we would win. And our product team has done just that. The connection is amazing to see. So let's talk about social media. Oh, it's so much of all of that. As I mentioned, the Buy Guide was real. They were fans of this product. So the Buy Guide was telling their fans and we were telling ours that the next quencher color was arriving and all of that was on our own DTC, stanley1913.com, and it continued to build. We had the proof points that people were coming to buy our product and they would come to their stores to buy our product. And so you started out with these influencers who liked you to begin with, much in the same way Post Malone liked Crocs. Did you then reach out to other influencers on TikTok or Instagram? Or was that more your fan base sort of generating marketing content on your behalf? It's become the latter. The fan base has taken over. Every hour, videos are on TikTok of excited consumers hunting, hauling, or unboxing their stanley. It no longer belongs to us in many ways, but that's why we continue to innovate and bring new things to continue the excitement. So we have even more of those videos evangelizing our brand on our behalf, but all organic and authentic. At some point, does that get tricky when you don't have control of how people are using your products or brands? Now it's all good, but at some point, are you worried that TikTokers have more influence in how stanley is perceived than the company itself does? Sure. I mean, that's always the risk of a popular brand. We see some of that today where the quencher is not designed to be leakproof, but yet we continue to see people on TikTok literally turning it over so that it leaks and saying it's not leakproof, which is humorous in a way. But things like that we would prefer are not on social media. They're accurate, but nor is it something we're advertising is something that it isn't. So those kinds of things are where it can get a little bit out of hand, but it allows us to now innovate where we have new things arriving in 2024. So as you said, the brand is quite traditional. It had long been associated with sustainability, having one thermos that you never had to replace. So how do you stay true to the history when you're also trying to tap new markets and grow sales? Do you worry at all about losing your core customer? Well, certainly you always want to have that balance. What we've heard time and time again is our loyal followers who were with us for so many years, they're telling all of their wives and daughters and friends, I told you Stanley was cool. I knew it all along. So we get a lot of those stories. Yes, you're right. Building a more sustainable, less disposable life and world is something that Stanley takes very seriously. So even the quencher is 90% from recycled stainless steel. The amount of single use plastic we like to believe we have removed from the daily life of people staying hydrated is significant, but we want to make sure we're introducing new ways to continue the loyal consumer while bringing many, many new people under the tent. The diversity of the Stanley fandom over the last three years is what has been so incredibly exhilarating for all of us. I've said this to the team here at Stanley for a while. It's the airport test. When I first started with Crocs, if you saw a pair of Crocs at the airport, you were lucky to see a pair. By the time I left Crocs, you would see hundreds of pairs of Crocs at the airport. So I always use the airport test as a great barometer for any brand's popularity and where it is in the zeitgeist. And certainly I've been fortunate to have two of the brands that I've worked on be part of that. Now the ascent to the summit begins. We firmly believe that we will become one of the leading lifestyle brands in the world over the next few years. Yeah, I like that idea of sort of different use cases, different consumer segments, you know, just understanding all the different ways that any product, you know, that a manufacturer produces could be used. So just taking a step back, you know, you as a leader walk into a place like Crocs or a place like Stanley and you see opportunity, but that involves change. So what are some of the first steps that you take? You know, you said listening to the existing employees was one of them, but what else do you do to sort of mobilize a company, a team towards a new vision for the future? I lead almost every day in every part of my life with an unmistakable sense of what's possible. And that's what I believe I brought to Stanley. You know, I joined Stanley in April of 2020, which was a pretty rough time to join a company as a new president. As we all know what was happening in the world. But on my very first day, obviously all of us were on video. We were all in our basements or kitchens or bedrooms or wherever we were as we figured out this new world in April of 2020. You know, in verse, it wasn't Shakespeare, it wasn't Tupac, but it rhymed at least. But it said what we were going to do. And so last year I brought it out again and I read it to the team and I couldn't get through it without getting choked up. Yeah. How did people react initially though? And so I reread it last year and I couldn't get through it because the team made everything happen that I said was going to happen. And that was an incredible moment for me, but it started with that and setting a vision, having that unmistakable sense of what's possible, listening to our team and then taking some risks and that set some people back. That was change. We were the $70 million sleepy little brand known for the hammer-tone green bottle. And doing a pink one designed to reach a new audience was change and change is hard for people. But you have to believe, you have to take the risk and you have to have that unmistakable sense of what's possible. podcast_summary: In this podcast episode, Terrence Riley, the president of Stanley and former chief marketing officer of Crocs, discusses how consumer goods move from being uncool to trendy. He shares his experience with Crocs' resurgence, highlighting the role of a collaboration with Post Malone in driving popularity and relevance. Riley emphasizes the importance of authenticity and taking risks in finding endorsers and influencers for brand partnerships. He also discusses the listening aspect of marketing, highlighting the value of social media and internal team input in understanding consumer preferences. Riley explains the process of revitalizing the Stanley brand, emphasizing the need to balance tradition and sustainability with new market growth. He shares how Stanley has leveraged social media and organic marketing content from fans to increase brand awareness and engagement. Riley concludes by discussing his leadership approach, including open communication, servant leadership, and the importance of humility, humor, and recognition in building a successful team dynamic.

Introduction:
Terrence Riley, President of Stanley and former CMO of Crocs, shares his insights on how both companies successfully transformed from being under the radar to becoming trendy and relevant. He discusses the key strategies and moments that led to their resurgence and offers valuable lessons on brand revitalization.

Key Moments:
- [07:10]: Terrence shares how Crocs' collaboration with Post Malone kickstarted their success, leveraging the authenticity of the artist's fandom for the brand.
- [09:34]: He explains the importance of relevance over awareness and how collaboration with celebrities and brands helped drive growth for Crocs.
- [14:19]: Terrence highlights the significance of listening to consumers and paying attention to cultural trends, citing the example of Kentucky Fried Chicken collaboration with Crocs.
- [18:04]: He shares his approach to listening to consumers and gathering insights, including social media and team input.
- [22:32]: Terrence discusses the shift in consumer perception of Stanley from a traditional, male-oriented brand to a more diverse and modern lifestyle brand.
- [27:55]: He emphasizes the role of innovation and continuous product development in sustaining brand growth and capturing new consumer segments.
- [31:22]: Terrence addresses the challenge of maintaining brand authenticity and managing brand perception in the age of user-generated content on platforms like TikTok.
- [34:18]: He explains how Stanley stays true to its heritage of sustainability while appealing to new markets and customer segments.

Main Takeaways:
1. Collaboration with relevant influencers and celebrities can inject new relevance and authenticity into a brand, driving growth and engagement.
2. Listening to consumers, both through social media and internal team input, is crucial for understanding their needs, preferences, and cultural trends.
3. Innovation is key to sustaining brand growth and remaining competitive in a rapidly evolving market.
4. Balancing tradition and heritage with the need to adapt and appeal to new consumer segments is essential for long-term success.
5. Creating a culture of servant leadership, humility, and recognition fosters employee engagement and commitment to the brand's vision.
